resource.chars:
The edge of the fast ice in this season exactly resembles
that exposed on our arrival; owing to snow fall
the ice inshore has thickened this year in the 
same manner and in fact not only the floe
but the snow slopes + ice foot are note in 
appearance similar to what they were on our
arrival in <s>the<s> Feb <sup>1902<sup> and this not only in the near
but on the farther side of Cape Armitage
I think therefore there can be no doubt that the
ice which left this spot last season was the
result of one season's freezing and therefore that
the <s>berg<s> it has been freed of ice for two season
in succession

Until the ship was frozen in we suffered continual
annoyance in landing our huts etc from <s>the<s> a 
considerable swell against which Hut Point afforded
but a partial protection; this year there has <sup>so far<sup> been 
little or no swell at the edge of the fast ice
This can only be due to the lateness of the season
+ the manner in which the pack has hung about
C. Bird as reported by Captain Colbeck

The ice immediately about hut point and in our
small bay is now cracked in all directions so that
should the main floe move out, the bay ice will
undoubtedly quickly follow it

Though we entered the bay early in February the
ship was not frozen in until March 24<sup>th<sup> and
after that date the ice continued to break away
